instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.Q7010: What is Q7010? Q7010 controls whether or not PPDCIN_G3H will be let through to the PP3V42_G3H power supply, often this circuit area is not working because D7010 has died or corroded. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.D7012: What is D7012? Diode between ground and gate of Q7010 on 2013-2015 year model macbook airs, necessary for Q7010 to allow PPDCIN_G3H to flow through to PP3V42_G3H power supply input. When this diode dies or corrodes, PP3V42_G3H input will not have any voltage, and chargers will not turn on. This can often be the problem if a system only works with a knockoff charger/bench power supply. .
definitions.Q7180: What is Q7180? Inrush limiter transistor that must be told by the ISL6259 that it is safe to allow charger voltage to pass through to the computer. This needs CHGR_AGATE and CHGR_SGATE to be pulled down in order for it to close and allow voltage through to the system, current sensing failures as well as ISL6259 failures can cause this to happen. .
definitions.A1286: What is A1286? A1286 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2009 , Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2255, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2330, 820-2532, 820-2523, 820-2533, 820-2850, 820-2915, 820-3330..
definitions.R7005: What is R7005? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .
definitions.PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT: What is PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT? PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT is PPBUS_G3H backlight voltage entering the backlight boost circuit once the transistor has been told to allow it through. .
definitions.Q7706: What is Q7706? Q7706 takes PPBUS_G3H's main 12.6v and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q7706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R7788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q7706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..

threads.title: MBA <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no boot
threads.message:
This board had some sticky food stuff around <CAPACITOR>C7796</CAPACITOR>, I resoldered the cap after cleaning up the area.
However, the problem, no green light on mag and no boot remains. Turns out the mag adapter is dead as well, so I am using a MBP mag adapter and want to ask, to make sure that this is not going to do further damage?
With that working MBP mag in place, and with battery plugged in I have voltage as per specs on all <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> up to <TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR>, but nothing gets past. 
Being very new at this I am hesitant to induce voltage, I do not want to fry things.
What would you suggest I do from here?

threads.title: MBA <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no boot
threads.message:
Are you using original Magsafe 2 60/85W charger?
Don't use 1-->2 adapter.

Post exact voltage for <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> (F7140) and 3V42 (L7095).
Also check <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: MBA <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no boot
threads.message:
I just found another MBA charger, a Mag 2 albeit had come with another very dead MBA (with tea in it). However , that charger also does not give me any voltage at J7000.
Since both my Mag 2 chargers are not giving me any voltage at P1 and P2 of J7000, I am using the Mag1, which came with the 2009/10 Macbook Pros.

It fits as long as the board is not in the alu casing, and gives me 19V at P1 and P2 of J7000, and power as far as <TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR>.
For the purpose of testing I have no choice but to keep using it, I suppose:
I tried with the other DC in board (of the tea damaged machine), but no changes as far as voltage on J7000 with Mag2 chargers I have here.
So , measured with the Mag1 in place, all testpoint show 0V:

F7140: 0V
L7095: 0V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>: Testpoint 804 and <RESISTOR>R7100</RESISTOR> P1 : 0V <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR>:0V
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>: Probe 595: 0V <RESISTOR>R5185</RESISTOR>:0V
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>: Testpoint 639: 0V <TRANSISTOR>Q3000</TRANSISTOR>: 0V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>: <TRANSISTOR>Q5510</TRANSISTOR>: P2: 0V
<SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>: Not found on my boardview
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>: Probe 778: 0V <RESISTOR>R5198</RESISTOR>: 0V
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>: Not found on my boardview

I might be able to lay hands on a proper Mag 2 in a few days or so: I have a call out to a friend. Other than that it still seems that nothing goes past <TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR>....maybe the gate voltage is not right for it to pass the power?

threads.title: MBA <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no boot
threads.message: OK, plot thickens!! I just tried both Mag2 chargers on the other tea-damaged <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A ( I will call it board 'T') , and with both mags  I do have 14.9V on the two relevant J7000 points. This means that the chargers must be OK after all, but somehow do not register on the original board I am trying to fix.....Does that give you any clue as to where to look? And maybe the board T might not be beyond hope either?

threads.title: MBA <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no boot
threads.message: The good upshot is that my tea damaged board can serve as a donor now. While completely corroded in some sections with caps green and falling off, the <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_WORKS</SIGNAL> on that one , past <TRANSISTOR>Q7110</TRANSISTOR> up to <DIODE>D7005</DIODE>. I am about to confirm the ohm measurements for the resisters pertaining to the mosfet <TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR>, to see if one of them is messing with my gate voltage.

threads.title: MBA <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no boot
threads.message:
Magsafe 1 charger, even using 1--->2 adapter, will generate weird issue on 2015 machines.
There is a difference for the handshake protocol between MLB and charger.

The board from first post has leakage on the input stage and original Magsafe 2 charger detects that and gets blocked.
Common issue <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR>, or <DIODE>D7012</DIODE>.
Post exact value (measured onboard, ohm scale) for <RESISTOR>R7180</RESISTOR>/81, <RESISTOR>R7185</RESISTOR>/86 and <RESISTOR>R7012</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: MBA <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no boot
threads.message:
Cool, great learning curve, thanks so much
<RESISTOR>R7180</RESISTOR>: 99.2 k
<RESISTOR>R7181</RESISTOR>: 61.8 k
<RESISTOR>R7185</RESISTOR>: 474 k
<RESISTOR>R7186</RESISTOR>: 333 k
<RESISTOR>R7012</RESISTOR>: OL

I have <RESISTOR>R7012</RESISTOR> on my donor board reading 68 k !!!
Anything I should know to safely remove and install it on my good board?

threads.title: MBA <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no boot
threads.message: Just solder correct value <RESISTOR>R7012</RESISTOR>...

threads.title: MBA <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no boot
threads.message: I hate to admit it, but I screwed this up. I just could not find a way to hold down that resister while soldering the ends, it kept sticking to my tools, just too tiny. Then I tried to use hot air, I did not get it to stick either, lots of flux, but no cigar..Finally one end of the resistor came off and it lost connectivity. Could you recommend a source to replace this resistor? And a means to attach it to the board? Sorry for the newbie questions, but one has to start somewhere...

threads.title: MBA <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no boot
threads.message:
You must put leaded solder on the board pads first, and use quality flux.
Then place the resistor and solder one pin.
Hot air will help to align if the flux is really good.
Get a good microscope, if you don't have one yet.

Search schematic of the scrap boards you have, for 68K resistor.
You can solder somehow even bigger size (0402); case you can pick it from normal laptop boards...

threads.title: MBA <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no boot
threads.message: Thank you for your patience and for taking the time to spell it out for me. Very much appreciated. I have a good microscope,the flux is the brand Louis recommended, but the source was Ebay, which is according to him not good enough...Anyway,I will order the real flux from Amtec and will find another resistor, with those specs on a donor board ,or buy it somewhere...I was thinking I could solder some copper leads to the pads and place the resistor elsewhere on the board, so I will not jeopardize neighboring components with my shaky attempts at soldering in such in such tiny spaces....I let you know when/if I get somewhere. Cheers,J

threads.title: MBA <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no boot
threads.message: One more question regarding that 68k resistor. How critical is it to get ALL the sub specs right, namely 1%  1/20W MF 201. I have a donor board ,an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, which has a 68K 5% 1/16W MF-LF 402 on it.  Also have been looking on ebay where I can get carbon film resistors rates 68k 1W +-5% . Those have handy legs on them, for me to  have something to hold on to when soldering to the pads and tuck out of the way after... Any thoughts on those options?

threads.title: MBA <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no boot
threads.message:
68K values is most important in this case.
Depending of that, original charger will recognize the board.
It will probably accept 62-75K, you can try that.
0201 is the size, but you can try to accomodate 0402.

I have a kit like this
[url]https://www.ebay.es/itm/0201-SMD-SMT-Assorted-Chip-Resistor-kit-106values-each-50pcs-strip-cut-pack/202589371456?hash=item2f2b447c40:g:6cIAAOxycmBSzk3o:rk:1:pf:0[/url]
and is more easy to use than the book, for 0201 size.

I recommend you to get book style for 0402-0805.
[url]https://www.ebay.es/itm/0201-0805-1206-0402-0603-1-SMD-SMT-Chip-Resistor-170-Valores-Sample-Book-DIY-B6/173666502412?hash=item286f54870c:m:mE5QHzTSxd1hpf-H64-5qdQ:rk:1:pf:0[/url]
I recommend you buy only resistors, not resistors + caps version (useless cap values)...

threads.title: MBA <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no boot
threads.message:
So I found a 68k resistor here locally, not an SMD, but one with legs.  I am improvising, to make up for my shaky hands and still  limited soldering skills: I attached a copper wire to P1 pad of <RESISTOR>R7012</RESISTOR> attached my new resistor and grounded it to a convenient ground in the hood. Made sure the wires are all insulated from other component.  Now I do have 14.9V at J 7000!

 I re-tested the points you asked me to check earlier, but all remains the same there 
??????F7140: 0V
L7095: 0V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>: Testpoint 804 and <RESISTOR>R7100</RESISTOR> P1 : 0V <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR>:0V
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>: Probe 595: 0V <RESISTOR>R5185</RESISTOR>:0V
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>: Testpoint 639: 0V <TRANSISTOR>Q3000</TRANSISTOR>: 0V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>: <TRANSISTOR>Q5510</TRANSISTOR>: P2: 0V
<SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>: Not found on my boardview
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>: Probe 778: 0V <RESISTOR>R5198</RESISTOR>: 0V
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>: Not found on my boardview

I measured again at <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> to see if mosfet <TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR> is now allowing voltage to come through, but there is nothing still...

threads.title: MBA <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no boot
threads.message: Post <TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR> voltages, with original Magsafe 2 charger; considering you get 15V at J7000.

threads.title: MBA <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no boot
threads.message: My <TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR> looks different from the boardview graphics, which shows 4 Pins called 1,4,5,6 in a different arrangement then what is on the board. On the board I have an 8 point component. Looking at the board with the fan/DCin board on the right: <TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR> with its 8 pins ( 4 each side) has 15.1V on the top left, and 14.1 on the top right. Am I right to assume that the left pin 15.1V then is my Source voltage, also present at P1 of <RESISTOR>R7012</RESISTOR> and that the right pin 14.1V must be my gate? <CAPACITOR>C7012</CAPACITOR> P2 also has 14.1V, so my gate voltage is lower as it is supposed to be, right? But it still does not open <TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR>....since there is nothing at <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR>. Maybe <TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR> is kaputt?

threads.title: MBA <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no boot
threads.message: I am checking <RESISTOR>R7010</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7011</RESISTOR>, both have correct ohms...Do not know how to test Cap <CAPACITOR>C7012</CAPACITOR>

threads.title: MBA <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no boot
threads.message:
Identify <TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR> pins from schematic; boardview doesn't correspond.
Pin1 is marked on the chip package.

Gate of <TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR> should have 6.8V; change <DIODE>D7012</DIODE>.
Be aware, is not an easy job.
One time I didn't have original in stock and I used one in SOD27 (DO-35) package.
I conveniently cutted off the pins and soldered to other component terminals.

threads.title: MBA <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no boot
threads.message: OK, I will order some of the diodes you pointed out SOD27 (DO-35) from Mouser. If you have any suggestion what other components are used frequently in Macbook repair 2009-now, I could order them all at once...Must read up on what the diode designations mean...I am without the faintest clue...Would this one work?:[url]https://www.ebay.ca/itm/10PCS-1N4148-Diode-Zener-100V-200mA-Rectifier-Radial-DO-35/322852171095?hash=item4b2b7d2d57:g:eTgAAOSwBjdZ9MIA:rk:3:pf:0[/url]

threads.title: MBA <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no boot
threads.message:
I used that "monster"package because didn't have original that time, nor even from scrap.
Buy GDZT2R6.8 and be very carefull when change it.
If you had problems to change a 0201 resistor, I cannot imagine what will happen with that very tiny diode.
This is the reason I mentioned the option for a diode with legs.

Don't forget to apply leaded solder on the diode pads before place it on the board.

threads.title: MBA <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no boot
threads.message: Thank you for all your help, it is so much appreciated. And yes, the tinyness of the components are a real challenge for me, but I am determined to learn how to do it, if it is the last thing I do. Largely my shakiness is from excitement, it is all so new and mysterious...but I am learning quickly. I did not realize for instance that you would prep the tiny components with a bit of leaded solder until you just now mentioned it. Makes perfect sense!! I have a few  of 2009/2010 Mbps I got on Ebay to be my learning aids, ( I was hoping to restore them by replacing the Tantallon cap) Working with this forum is the most exciting way to go about learning..However the components on the Mbas, which my friends give me to fix,  are even smaller...One question on diodes: I suppose I can find some on my donor boards, but I am not sure what designation is important...

threads.title: MBA <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no boot
threads.message: I looked on some of my donor boards for a diode, and found plenty with the 6.8V designation on the A1268 board. However, the symbol is different. The one on the 00165 board has one triangle pointing away from ground towards the horizontal bar. All donor board diodes I have seen have 2 triangles pointing towards each other. Is this just a slightly different symbol still meaning the same? Can I still use those on the donor boards? I also ordered some monsters, as you put it , but perfect for my currently still limited skill level: [URL]https://www.ebay.ca/itm/291528748673[/URL]. In case the donor board double triangle diodes are not useful...

threads.title: MBA <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no boot
threads.message:
Original is 6.8V zener diode; pretty sure will work any from 5V6 to 8V2 range.
Using fake charger, machine will work even shorting <DIODE>D7012</DIODE> to ground.

Te zener voltage is marked on the schematics; doesn't matter package symbol.

threads.title: MBA <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no boot
threads.message: I finally have some time and I am setting out this morning to transplant the 6.8V diode from my <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> donor to the MBA. Just wondering if you would help me clear up a bit of foggy understanding as far as orientation goes? I suppose I can determine the orientation of the diode I will harvest by measuring resistance and that way determine which way the one way valve for current is oriented, right? And then install it accordingly with the non conducting side to ground. Is that right? Here is where the diode will be coming from...[ATTACH alt="Screen shot 2019-03-08 at 11.13.40 AM.png" type="full"]47190._xfImport[/ATTACH]

threads.title: MBA <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no boot
threads.message:
You talk about bidirectional TVS diode.
I'm not sure if it works as you need, for very small current; but you can try.
No matters how you solder it, is bidirectional.

TVS diode are used to protect against overvoltage, sinking high currents...

threads.title: MBA <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no boot
threads.message: I tried and tried,but could not get any of them to stick. I think I will have to wait for the monster zener diode with legs aka pins to arrive from China. I really suck at tiny soldering still. Must watch more videos on it, I suppose....

threads.title: MBA <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no boot
threads.message:
First time I soldered <DIODE>D7012</DIODE>, I lost two; is a nightmare.
You must put leaded solder on its pads first.

threads.title: MBA <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no boot
threads.message: Yes, I was quite frustrated and had to call repeatedly on my infinite patience.Thank you for letting me know that I am not alone in finding this super tricky. The tiny bits either flick away or get stuck to the iron. I will educate myself , there must be some youtube channel that discusses how to go about this. I shall never surrender....if anyone else can do it, then so can I. Cheers, you are an awesome teacher

threads.title: MBA <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no boot
threads.message:
You can't solder it with iron tip.
Use it only to place it on the flux, in it's place.
Then use hot air to solder it.
Microscope should help you a lot.
Put more flux there, so hot air do not move it away...

threads.title: MBA <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no boot
threads.message: It turns out that the 6.8V multidirectional diodes are not a replacement for the 6.8V Zener diode. Well, if nothing else it was good exercise in removing diodes from the donor boards. I added leaded solder as I removed them from the donor board, at least they cannot get away that easy, and I have them primed with leaded solder ready to reinstall. After a lot of tries I did get it into place. Would have been so cool if that would have done the trick, since there are lots of them on the old board in the audio circuits, but alas, no cigar. So I am back to zener diode shopping...Being in Canada makes buying stuff from Louis' website pretty expensive, shipping is over the top, for reasons beyond my comprehension.

threads.title: MBA <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no boot
threads.message: I can buy these diodes here in Canada, and get them faster than from China of course. Would a 1W diode be appropriate in this application?   [url]http://vi.raptor.ebaydesc.com/ws/eBayISAPI.dll?ViewItemDescV4&item=183650841004&category=181899±=1&ds=0&t=1552801163871[/url]

threads.title: MBA <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no boot
threads.message:
<DIODE>D7012</DIODE> has a very low current for its zener voltage
Bigger diodes could require higher current to enter in zener zone.
Check datasheet specifications of the one you want to buy.
0.25-0.5W will work for sure; probably 1W too, just try.

You can short <DIODE>D7012</DIODE> to ground and use fake charger, it should work...

threads.title: MBA <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no boot
threads.message: OK so have to admit defeat. I gave up on the board and the zener diodes, just purchased another logic board and just installed it. Still no light on the charger, no boot. Could it be the DC in board which is causing my problem? I also disconnected the keyboard when trying to boot, in order to make sure that no short in the keyboard would interfere. But nada.

threads.title: MBA <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no boot
threads.message: Nevermind, she did boot up after all with my new logic board. Appears that the battery is fried and the machine will shut down immediately when I plug it in. The LCD screen was shaky, but stabilized and now is going without flicker....I am getting a new battery and call is a day.

threads.title: MBA <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no boot
threads.message:
Just buy a fake charger for the original board.
It should then work with a simple short instead of <DIODE>D7012</DIODE>.

threads.title: MBA <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no boot
threads.message: OK, I did throw the towel on the old logic board we discussed above, and bought a working one on Ebay. I know it is cheating, but wtf, I am a newbie and got tired of messing with it. Put in the new logic board,: it booted up fine for about 10 min, until I removed some fingerprints smudges on the LCD screen, upon which I lost my backlight. So I did the reseating of the connector, checked the fuse ,which is fine, and then assumed that the screen (which was the original screen in a water damaged machine), might have been compromised when it shorted, and bought another screen. But alas, I still have no backlight. The machine boots, runs well on an external monitor. Now if I could please have some help on finding what else might be the issue...So now I have a new used logic board, a new used screen, and a brand new battery...

threads.title: MBA <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no boot
threads.message:
Do you get image on internal screen, only missing backlight?
The forum is full with information about backlight issues, especially for 00165 boards...

threads.title: MBA <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no boot
threads.message:
Yes, I do have the image, only it is very dark. I can run an external screen, so the machine is fine otherwise.
I looked at some of the forum backlight info, and did some measurements. I have nothing on <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>, 0V. So it must be what generates <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>. I 'll keep digging...

threads.title: MBA <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no boot
threads.message: OK, I tested <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR> which has voltage only on p2 ands p5, 3.3V each. Then I looked at <CAPACITOR>C7782</CAPACITOR> which was corroded enough to nearly fall off....

threads.title: MBA <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no boot
threads.message: And now, for something completely different: After I removed <CAPACITOR>C7782</CAPACITOR>, the LCD now is operational.....wtff?

threads.title: MBA <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no boot
threads.message: How does the Master Louis say it: Baddabing! Rebooted a few times, seems stabil!!
